titles.title: C
C - The Money of Soul and Possibility Control
[C]
C: The Money of Soul and Possibility
Control
C The Money of Soul and Possibility Control
C - Control
[C] - Control - The Money and Soul of Possibility
С - Парите могат да контролират душата
C: پول روح و کنترل احتمالات
C
[C] The Money of Soul and Possibility Control
「C」

recommendations.recommendation: I have to agree with the other comments here; the lack of episodes had quite the negativ impact on the story, which on the other hand contained some truly unique and interesting setting... lots of wasted potential in this department. Even one of the otherwise good fighting scenes was just cut at the end. So everything feels rushed and confusing which makes it hard to keep up with the already thinned out story.
Good premise, but poor execution. Plot is rushed, the animation is the worst of the season, and the characters are too one-dimensonal. Only watch it if you don`t have high expectations.

Sadly, the interesting premise of the show ended up being little more than a facade for a generic shonen flick. Some well animated scenes are the only thing redeemable about this anime, it wasted many eps on meaningless battles, built up one heck of a confusing pseudostory and never cared to elaborate on any of it. The rushed ending also created more questions than it solved. Sadly, it`s still one of the better shows of the spring 2011 season

It`s just the best for 11 episodes. You think it was too rush? Don`t you think the finance is rush everyday? Rush is good! Rush is must to be! The more the worse. No `potention` for any longer run. It should be done asap! Best plot anime of early 2011.
Wonderfully deep and asks some real questions. Who`d have thought that finance and economics could form the basis of a great series?
New concept of story, battles a little meh but overall good till now.

The first half was really good, but i felt like the ending as rushed to much..
Still a good watch if your looking for something new

26 or more episodes crammed in to 11. An obviously high budget anime cut short to the point of confusing the watcher.
Great animation and style, don`t bother if you`re looking for a deep story.

Ended too fast = Storyline get mess up + confusing and too many unresolves. I don`t know why they decide to end it at episode 11. This kind of anime should around 26+ episodes. Honestly what a waste for a completely original anime. Hope entire production staffs commit suppeku for ignorance!!

Thats something. They try to put financial crisis into a anime. Fine. But they don`t get the idea what causes it, don`t they? I mean, just making people or landscapes disappear just isn`t what happends if you blow up a economy by gambling. There are, however, some interesting points. The main-character is a pretty good guinea-pig for all this. Since the story is limited to 11 eps the climax is about to come. I admit i`m quite curious what it will be: crap or brilliant?

A supernatural take on the ups and downs typical to economic systems, with a political backdrop of the current Great Depression, utilizing a number of the main actors and movers thereof, the IMF, the World bank, and the Federal Reserve via the US. The effects of fiat currency, the Midas note (read Federal Reserve note), a debt-based system, the use of an inflationary-deflationary model, and ultimately the will to use such to subjugate every aspect of peoples` present and futures leading to only which can be called world domination.
While a number of morals arise, primary to the current global situation and the story backdrop is the utter fallibility of fiat currency, and the dangers posed by the ultimate agenda of those who would make it and those insipid enough to indebted themselves to it. It`s a fun vision of an otherwise mundane, and yet critical aspect of everyday life.
Good show, but it really crumpled. 7 is fair rating.
Nice plot

Very underrated in my opinion. This anime has amazing animation, great OST, awesome story concept. Now the bad the characters arnt really memorable and only 11eps if this had more i`m sure it would had been a lot better

I was a little put off at first because of the proxy battle aspect but its actually a very good watch, one of the few animes airing currently that I am keeping up on instead of just waiting for Blu-ray

Simply failed quite to live up to what could have been a very interesting idea. Not only was the idea not improvised and explained properly, the series was rushed. Final Verdict: The show could have been 10 times better if idea was utilized properly.

That anime have the potencial to be really great but why only 11 eps :( It easyly can have at least 30 eps with a plot like that ... Anyway the plot is superb but it should`ve been expressed in more series !

If your looking for a good, imaginitive, anime that sucks you in from the very first episode, this is for you! Though it gets sort of confusing towards the end, so you may have to re-watch a few episodes to understand things.

Good series, very short only 11 episodes. Primary characters are developed enough for the plot. Very adult themes about money and economics with a trainer/summon dynamic. All in all a good watch was entertained the whole way through worth the time.
Amazing. #1 anime this season by far.

This is my second time recommending an anime(been here since 2006)
MUST SEE!!
surprisingly good!
Absolutely fantastic and addictive. Don`t miss it !

I believe the point of this anime was to show how the monetary system and corruption can bring our world to ruin and destroy our futures. If it had of been longer than 11 episodes I believe that point could have been easily misconstrued or detracted from by a longer series. If you`ve seen the Zeitgeist films or EndGame - Blueprint For Global Enslavement, and you enjoy anime; this is a MUST WATCH for you!

anime.description: http://anidb.net/ch26534 [Kimimaro], raised by his maternal grandmother after the disappearance of his father and the death of his mother, is a scholarship student whose only dream is to live a stable and normal life. One day he is visited by a peculiar man who forcefully offers him a large sum of money with the collateral being his future. Doubting at first, he decides to use the money, causing him to be immediately taken into a mysterious area known as The Financial District.

tag.name: maintenance tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: hard-working
tag.description: Describes someone, who is constantly, regularly, or habitually active or occupied.

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: calling your attacks
tag.description: "GIGAAAAAA DRIIIIIILLL BREAKEEEEEERRR" If you can do something more impressive than just throw a punch, your attack(s) must have an equally impressive name. More than that, you have to call it out as you launch the attack. It doesn`t matter if it`s a martial arts move, a magical spell or your secret superweapon, if you can`t say its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Having a special attack is always a must, but not impressive enough. Every special attack needs a name. A really awesome and outstanding name which is easy to remember and even easier and impressive to yell. Because it just is not enough to name your attack. No, to unleash the full power of your attack, you have to call its name in your most MANLY and LOUDEST voice. It does not matter whether it is a martial arts move, a magical spell or flying drills from your mecha, if you can`t call its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Not a requirement but wearing shades while calling your attack makes it at least twice as cool, moreover giving your mecha or magical companion shades too results in an immeasurable level of awesomeness, bringing down every enemy just through the POWER OF YOUR VOICE. A standard feature of practically every mecha, mahou shoujo, high fantasy, or martial arts anime. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: super power
tag.description: Be it an ancient Greek Heracles, a cybernetic muscle-man, or a fourteen year-old girl in a mini-skirted sailor suit. As long as they have super powers, they`re in the show.

tag.name: future
tag.description: Anime that fall under the future category are the ones that have a society that could have originated from ours. In most cases it should go hand to hand with sci-fi since we expect the future to consist of advanced technology, however, in the case where it`s explicitly stated in the story that the anime takes place "x years into the future", the state of technology doesn`t matter as long as it`s long into the future. The anime can be set in an alternative universe not tied with our own, as long as it has a futuristic feel to it. This category sports quite a lot of anime, mostly stemming from SciFi, but not necessarily only from there.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: university
tag.description: Since college/university students are typically at least eighteen years old, with stories covering mature everyday life topics, you will find the college setting quite often in seinen and josei anime. Topics that can now be covered - as compared to High School settings - are higher education (i.e. coping with higher intellectual stress), the more adult party life (i.e. alcohol, smoking, sex), the issues of daily life vs. studying - especially when having to work to pay for bills, and finally the possible friction between those in and out of college.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Japan is a sovereign island nation in East Asia. Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies off the eastern coast of the Asian mainland and stretches from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and China in the southwest. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: new
tag.description: Not based on anything, the story is a new work, usually made up by the people involved in creating the anime. Generally if an original work (原作) credit is given, it will be to the studio, or director, or other members of the production team.

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is Earth`s largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth`s total land area and 8.7% of the Earth`s total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: angst
tag.description: A feeling of general discomfort and uneasiness is present due to either trivial or more serious reasons, often accompanied by depression. Warning: may contain copious amounts of brooding and sighing. Etymology: "Angst" is a German word meaning fear or anxiety.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: proxy battles
tag.description: In our terms, a proxy battle is a battle where humans use creatures/robots to do the fighting for them, either by commanding those creatures/robots or by simply evolving them/changing them into battle mode. Often the training aspect is also involved, or in some cases the proxies are nothing more than holographic representatives of some other variation of competition (like for example a card game). While many popular shounen anime fit under this category, it`s not limited to shounen anime.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: conspiracy
tag.description: The conspiracy thriller (or paranoid thriller) is a sub-genre of the thriller which flourished in the 1970s in the US (and was echoed in other parts of the world) in the wake of a number of high-profile scandals and controversies (most notably Vietnam, the assassination of President Kennedy, Chappaquiddick and Watergate), and which exposed what many people regarded as the clandestine machinations and conspiracies beneath the orderly fabric of political life. The protagonists of conspiracy thrillers are often journalists or amateur investigators who find themselves (often inadvertently) pulling on a small thread which unravels a vast conspiracy that ultimately goes "all the way to the top".

tag.name: dystopia
tag.description: A dystopia (from Ancient Greek: δυσ-, "bad, ill", and Ancient Greek: τόπος, "place, landscape"; alternatively cacotopia, or anti-utopia) is, in literature, an often futuristic society that has degraded into a repressive and controlled state, often under the guise of being utopian. Dystopian literature has underlying cautionary tones, warning society that if we continue to live how we do, this will be the consequence. A dystopia, thus, is regarded as a sort of negative utopia and is often characterized by an authoritarian or totalitarian form of government. Dystopias usually feature different kinds of repressive social control systems, a lack or total absence of individual freedoms and expressions and constant states of warfare or violence. Dystopias often explore the concept of humans abusing technology and how humans individually and collectively cope with technology that has evolved too quickly such as the car, the flamethrower or the microwave. A dystopian society is also often characterized by widespread poverty and brutal political controls such as a large military-like police.

tag.name: coming of age
tag.description: In the strict sense the Coming of age describes a young person`s transition from adolescence to adulthood. In anime the term is used in a more general sense where the protagonists have to face a challenge, make an important decision in their life, take on responsibility, or learn a lesson, and by overcoming these obstacles they reach a higher level of maturity.

tag.name: parental abandonment
tag.description: In Japan it is a common custom for parents to leave their children alone at home and embark on a lifelong trip around the world once they hit the tender age of 14, sometimes even earlier. Of course this is done because the parents believe their children are independent enough to get their act together. But little do they know about the small secrets their offspring has, such as a childhood fiancé(e) or even a forbidden incestuous love between their (often not-blood-related) children. Of course aside from having a huge house, financial support is provided as well. Usually through the means of MAGICAL MONEY. In rare cases the parents actually die (shortly) before embarking on their world-trip, which is self-evidently used as an important plot device in the development of the child.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: rotten world
tag.description: A rotten world is a setting or situation where the jaded notion that "anything that can go wrong will go horribly wrong" almost always applies. Oppression, perpetual warfare, lawlessness, despair or other forms of mental instability, and other highly undesirable factors tend to be rampant.

tag.name: open-ended
tag.description: The ending of this anime is left to the viewer`s imagination. There are no clear hints at a definite story outcome, several possibilities are presented without closure, or the story ends suddenly without explanation. There may also be room for a sequel.

tag.name: noitaminA
tag.description: noitaminA (ノイタミナ) – Animation written backwards – is a Fuji Television programming block, devoted to anime, broadcast each Thursday night from 00:45 to 1:15. It was launched with the intention of expanding the target audience beyond the typical young male demographic. The timeslot was expanded from half an hour to a full hour in 2010, and now airs Thursday nights from 00:45 to 1:45. noitaminA aired its first non-anime series in 2010, with the premiere of the live-action adaptation of Moyashimon. On April 15, 2010, Fuji TV and FUNimation announced an agreement that allows FUNimation to simulcast series from the noitaminA block in North America within an hour of their airing in Japan.

tag.name: surreal
tag.description: Refers to things or occurrences that are generally bizarre or dreamlike, with the relentless capability of replacing reality through the eyes of the beholder. Surrealism is boundless, limited only by thought itself.

tag.name: be careful what you wish for
tag.description: Be careful what you wish for... your wish may actually come true. This is an age-old philosophical problem of what human beings think they want and what is actually good for them. The power to wish for anything can be very dangerous and usually — as a moral lesson — yields unexpected / unwanted results. A contract with the devil is a specific case of this; receiving great power, especially from a devil, is usually a double edged sword.

tag.name: boy meets girl
tag.description: A classical type of plot in story writing, where the story begins with a boy meeting a girl leading to romantic development between the two. More often than not the boy loses the girl later on and has to find her again.

tag.name: economics
tag.description: Economics is the social science that studies economic activity to gain an understanding of the processes that govern the production, distribution and consumption of goods and services in an economy. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: poverty
tag.description: It refers to the condition of not having the means to afford basic human needs.

tag.name: butchered foreign languages
tag.description: In this anime, some characters "speak" foreign languages, successfully making the audience`s ears bleed. That is especially true if the viewer is a native speaker of or otherwise proficient in the languages in question. The foreigners in the show do not seem to take much notice of the fact that their supposed native languages are being massacred. In fact, oftentimes they also actively participate in the butchering of said languages. That happens, of course, because they, too, are voiced by Japanese people without knowledge of the language they`re supposed to speak, or to pretend to speak at any rate.

tag.name: secret organisation
tag.description: A secret organisation or secret society is an organisation whose activities and inner functioning are concealed from non-members. The society may or may not attempt to conceal its existence itself. Examples of historical and existing secret societies include Freemasonry, the Knights Templar, the Rosicrucians, Skull and Bones, the Thule Society, and the Illuminati.

tag.name: cosmic reset
tag.description: All events that occurred up to a certain point are mysteriously undone, as if the Universe pressed a rewind button. This usually means some characters are being given another chance to unknowingly play out events differently, perhaps to prevent certain consequences from the previous time line`s actions. Occasionally they become doomed to repeat portions of their life over and over again until an individual event or series of events are performed correctly in just the right way, as seemingly to gain the Universe`s approval.

tag.name: Engrish
tag.description: Engrish is actually a mispronunciation of English, as can be the result of someone, who does not have English as their primary language of origin (such as Japanese or Chinese). Occasionally characters in the original Japanese dialogue version of an anime will speak in English... however; this often still requires the assistance of subtitles, for while the words are meant to be said in English, the sentence structure and letter pronunciation may still be strongly related to the person’s primary language.

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO CHARACTER
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to character tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what characters they should be assigned to.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: multi-anime projects
tag.description: Many anime are created as part of larger projects encompassing many shows without direct relation to one another. Normally, there is a specific idea in mind: for example, the http://anidb.net/t4859 [Young Animator Training Project] aims to stimulate the on-the-job training of next-generation professionals of the anime industry, whereas the http://anidb.net/t3763 [World Masterpiece Theatre] aims to animate classical stories from all over the world.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: ending
tag.description: This is a container tag to house meta-like tags relating to how endings of anime play out.

character.name: Yoga Kimimaro
character.description: Kimimaro Yoga is the main protagonist. His mother died and his father is missing, so he was raised by relatives. Currently he lives alone and goes to university. He dreams of a normal life with a normal family. He gets dragged into an abnormal place called "the financial district". There he has many encounters and has to fight.

character.name: Msyu
character.description: Msyu is Kimimaro`s Asset, who takes the appearance of a beautiful girl and has the ability to conjure up fire based attacks.

character.name: Q
character.description: Q is Mikuni`s main Asset, as well as partner. She is often seen eating Midas money. She is known as the strongest Asset in Financial District.

character.name: Jennifer Satou
character.description: Jennifer Satou is a 31-year-old agent working for the International Monetary Fund who is investigating the Financial Districts and somehow was invited to become an Entré at the same time. She is also curious about Mikuni`s sudden interest in Kimimaro.

character.name: Mikuni Souichirou
character.description: Mikuni Souichirou is a 33-year-old veteran and wealthy Entre who meets Kimimaro in the financial district and takes an interest in his potential.

character.name: Itaneda
character.description: Itaneda is a chaffeur for Entres between the real world and the Financial District.

character.name: Ikuta Hanabi
character.description: Ikuta Hanabi is Kimimaro`s best friend and classmate. Kimimaro had romantic feelings for her despite the fact that she already has a boyfriend.

character.name: Masakaki
character.description: Masakaki is a strange being from the Financial District. He is a representative of the Midas Bank, and his job is to lure new Entres to the District. He often pops up around Kimimaro out of nowhere.

character.name: Takedazaki Shigeomi
character.description: Takedazaki Shigeomi is an information broker of the Financial District. Though he has a platinum Midas card and a hulking monkey-like Asset, it is unknown whether he participates in Deals or not.

character.name: Ebara Daisuke
character.description: Ebara Daisuke is the economics professor at Heisei Financial University. He was an Entre with a Gold Midas Card, but after his Deal with Kimimaro, he went bankrupt.

character.name: Ebara no Tsuma
character.description: She is the wife of Yoga`s lecturer, Ebara Daisuke.

character.name: Makita Naoya
character.description: Makita Naoya is an Entre who became Bankrupt and died at the very start of the story.

character.name: Sennoza Kou
character.description: Sennoza Kou is a 29-year old who is the head of a nonprofit organization that delivers vaccines to poor countries. He is a powerful Entré with the habit of asking his opponents beforehand to back out of the deal, although none have ever taken his offer.

character.name: Mikuni Takako
character.description: Mikuni Takako is Souchirou`s sister, who is very sick.

character.name: Mukudori Guild
character.description: An organisation inside the Japanese Financial District whose main objective is to minimise the effects of Deals upon the real world by gaining the most minimal income in Deals as possible. Their ultimate goal is to take over the Japanese Financial District.

episode.title: COMPLICATION 複雑
Complication
Complicação!
Complication: Fukuzatsu
episode.summary: Full-time college student Kimimaro works his fingers to the bone, but he’s still flat broke. That is until an odd fellow invites him to the Financial District, a parallel world where he can increase his cash flow—if he’ll invest his future as collateral. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CONVERSION 転換
Conversion
Conversão!
Conversion: Tenkan
episode.summary: When Kimimaro`s second deal is a desperate wager against one of his own professors, he gets a lesson on how devastating the consequences can be in real life. Later, Mikuni makes Kimimaro a tempting offer to join his Starling Guild. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CONSPIRACY 陰謀
Conspiracy
Conspiração!
Conspiracy: Inbou
episode.summary: While searching for clues about why he was chosen to be an Entrepreneur, Kimimaro makes an unsettling discovery after finding a notebook filled with numbers in his family’s storage. Meanwhile, an investigator following Mikuni takes interest in Kimimaro. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: COINCIDENCE 暗合
Coincidence
Coincidência!
Coincidence: Angou
episode.summary: After being hurled into the Financial District and meeting his asset, Mashu—a petite girl with candy-striped antlers—Kimimaro is forced into a deal against an opponent who wastes no time launching staggering attacks with his monstrous asset. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CONTROL 未来
Control (Future)
Controle (Futuro)!
Control: Mirai
episode.summary: The value of yen plummets, and the citizens of Japan enter a total state of panic. With C threatening to wipe out Japan completely, the country’s future relies on the result of a heated clash between Kimimaro and Mikuni in a deal to end all deals. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: COLLISION 衝突
Collision
Colisão!
Collision: Shoutotsu
episode.summary: America’s Financial District repels C, sending the chain reaction right back towards Japan. When Mizuni’s next move proves even more costly than the last, Sato banks on a plan to send him into bankruptcy—but the window of opportunity is small. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: COLLAPSE 破綻
Collapse
Colapso!
Collapse: Hatan
episode.summary: Entire countries go off the map or endure devastating changes as a chain reaction - called “C” - sweeps across the Asian continent. A desperate move to save Japan is not without its deficits, and Kimimaro discovers another connection with his dad. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CONFIDENCE 信用
Confidence
Confidência!
Confidence: Shin`you
episode.summary: Japan suffers severe losses as a neighboring Financial District nears bankruptcy. While Kimimaro tries to undo the damage he dealt to his professor’s future, Mikuni formulates an expensive plan to save an entire region from being erased from existence. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: COMPOSITION 組成
Composition
Composição!
Composition: Sosei
episode.summary: A look into Mikuni’s past reveals his introduction to the cold world of business, money and power. Later, the ever-curious Mashu analyzes her Entrepreneur’s behavior, calculating what makes him different from everyone else in the Financial District. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CONFLICT 葛藤
Conflict
Conflito!
Conflict: Kattou
episode.summary: Kimimaro’s new strategic approach to deals pays off with a decent winning streak. But when his next opponent offers him a bribe to forfeit, the young Entre is caught in existential conflict over his investment in the Starling Guild. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: CULTIVATION 修練
Cultivation
Cultivo!
Cultivation: Shuuren
episode.summary: Kimimaro learns the hard way that keeping a tight margin during a deal is quite a gamble if he doesn’t have Mashu’s trust. While deals in the Financial District continue to affect Japan, Mikuni deposits more of his wealth into the suffering economy. Source: crunchyroll
